name: Yellow-billed Stork
description: It has long legs suited for moving in shallow waters or wetlands, and a large beak resembling that of a stork, striking with its bright yellow color. The red bare patch around the eyes is also notable. The stork’s plumage is white with a faint pinkish hue, except for the wing flight feathers and tail, which shimmer in greenish-black. Males are larger than females.
spread_note: Sub-Saharan Africa except the south, western Madagascar
image_alt: Yellow-billed Stork, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 79–86 cm; tail length 16–19 cm; wingspan 1.5–1.7 m; weight 2.1–3 kg
attractions: When hunting, it stirs up murky water and mud with its feet, then catches prey with the curved tip of its beak. It also frequents rice fields. Typically, it forms small groups. It nests in colonies in trees, often with other wading birds. The nest, made of sticks, is built by both partners, with the male choosing the site. Construction takes 7–10 days.
breeding: The first yellow-billed storks appeared at the zoo in 1974. These were wild birds that arrived at Dvůr Králové Zoo via famous African animal transports, with two sent to Prague, one living until 1982. We didn’t keep them again until 2002, when two pairs arrived, one of which still lives at the zoo. The first chicks were successfully raised in 2011, and they have bred regularly since.
